subject: RE: [junit] source code management
msgSnippet: There s probably something really basic that you ve overlooked.  Are your test methods public?  Couple suggestions. 1. Post the source code of this
messageBody:
There's probably something really basic that you've overlooked. Are your
test methods public? Couple suggestions.

1. Post the source code of this CalendarTest class to the group.

2. Get the JUnit samples running from the command line before trying
anything with the IDE.

3. Try creating your first test case from the Vector test case sample that
comes with JUnit.

aside: Java packages conventionally have all lower case names (Calendar).

Scott Stirling
Macromedia

-----Original Message-----
From: Rick Denman


I am teaching a course in extreme programming this spring, and I am
planning to use JUnit in the IDE Kawa. I am a newbie to JUnit and to
this
group, so I searched the archives of this group for the answer to my
question. All I found was the same question (with no satisfactory
answer)
back in a thread in February of 2001.

Namely, when I try to add tests to my project by extending the TestCase
class, and then run JUnit (either statically or from the plugin), I get
a
message that looks like:

1)
warning(junit.framework.TestSuite$1)junit.framework.AssertionFailedError
:
No tests found in Calendar.CalendarTest at
Calendar.CalendarTest.main(CalendarTest.java:11)

In other words, the test cases are not being found. I have all the
parameters and classpath variables, etc. set up as described in the
previous thread, and the web directions for setting up JUnit in Kawa.

Has anyone found a solution to this problem?

Rick Denman
Southwestern University
